messageBody:
Jason Rogers wrote:
>
> See embedded comments...
> BTW: This should really be on the Ant user list, not the JUnit list ;)

Is the Ant user list under yahoogroups or is it elsewhere? I'd like to
browse that list too.


>
> > <target name="test" depends="compile.tests,run.mail.server"
> > if="junit.present"
> > description="Runs the JUnit test cases">
> > ...
> >
> > When I run Ant, without the mail server running, it
> > displays my error
> > output that
> > indicates that the connection to the server failed, bu
> > then it continues
> > on. What
> > do I need to do, to cause the build to stop, if the check fails?
>
> 'haltonfailure=yes' and/or 'haltonerror=yes' should work here.

Hmmm. I tried both of these and it says that the attributes are not
supported
by this task I've created.

I just took the simple sample application that was shown in the
documentation
and substituted the guts of the execute method with my logic. My class
is a
subclass of Task, as is the sample in the docs. Any idea how I add
support
for these attributes? Or better yet any pointers to documentation on how
to
customize Ant?


>
> > Also, can anyone give me some ideas as to how to kick off the mail
> > server? It is
> > a Java app. I guess I could do a <java ...> line, but how
> > do I make that
> > conditional?
> > Is there a way to set some "property", as a result of the
> > "dixiecheck",
> > such that
> > this app would be invoked based on that "property" or "condition"?
>
> does <dixiecheck/> startup DixieMail if it is not running? If so, make the
> server a singleton and "away you go."

It doesn't yet, but I guess I could. The server is a third party
application
that I downloaded and use, so I don't want to play with their source.

I was thinking of two ways to kick off the server (any other ideas are
welcome):

A) In the DixieCheck class, if the server is not running, launch it. I
must
admit, I'm new to Java, so I'm not sure of the appropriate way to do
this
(start another Java application from inside an app, like C's system()
call).

B) Have the dixiecheck Ant task somehow (how?) set a "property"and then
have
another Ant task that forks java and runs the mailserver, if the
"property"
is set (can I do a <java fork="yes" classname="..."
classpath="...">).

Any comments on either of these two? Any other suggestions? Any pointers
on
A and/or B?


Thanks Jason.
